text: Akt and mTORC1 Control the Activation of JNK during Necroptosis
JNK is a well-established regulator of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synthesis in a variety of systems [ 13 ] , [ 14 ] , [ 15 ] , [ 34 ] .

Therefore , the ability of Akt and mTORC1 inhibitors to block the increase in <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA lead us to examine their role in the activation of JNK during necroptosis .

Knockdown of Akt isoforms <extra_id_0> Akt1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Akt2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or inhibition of Akt prominently suppressed the necroptosis dependent increase in JNK and <extra_id_0> c-Jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation ( Fig . 6E , S6D , E ) suggesting that Akt may provide a link between <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and JNK activation .

Importantly , inhibition of Akt only inhibited the delayed , but not the early , increase in <extra_id_0> bFGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / zVAD.fmk induced JNK and <extra_id_0> c-Jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation ( Fig .

Knockdown of mTOR , rapamycin and the <extra_id_0> p70S6K <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibitor PF-4708671 also attenuated the necroptosis - associated increase in JNK and <extra_id_0> c-Jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation ( Fig . 6F , S6E , G , Fig .

Overall , these data suggested that the Akt-mTORC1 - <extra_id_0> S6K <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> axis , acting downstream from <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase , is required for the increase in JNK activity during necroptosis in L929 cells .
